p.s: The given excerpt displays scene fourthfour of the play Disgraced, Scene 4 written by Ayad Akhtar.
In this part Amir and his nephew Abe got into a heated argument on how to act around American authorities.
Amir Kapoor's relationship to Abe Hussein/Jensen changes quite a bit during this play.
Thus it is important to look at their relationship in the beginning of the play.

The first time Abe and Amir are associated together is in the first scene, where Abe and Amir's wife Emily Kapoor pressure Amir to show up for the trial of an Imam who was apperentlyapparently wrongfully accussedacused of terrorism.
Abe asks his uncle for help even though he knows that Amir is not a part of the Muslim community anymore of supports any believes muslims share.
Moreover he is extremlyextremely scared, maybe even terrified of people who are (un-) intentionally racist and patronizing towards him.
Emily, who's a white American woman, supports Abe and tries to convince Amir to go to the trial.
It's important to add that Emily is an artist displaying Islamic patterns and shames Amir for his old religion.
Abe, knowing all of this and still asking Amir for help, shows, that he looks up to Amir but also thinks that Amir can, while living his American life, still support his old community.
In the end, Amir goes to the trail of the Imam, which is going to be the downfall of his career.
This is because a magazine ends up writing about the trial, portraying Amir like he was the attorney for Imam Fareed.
Amir's boss reads the article and runs a background check on him, finding out he changed his name from a Muslim to a Hindu name and gets suspicious of Amir.
This leads to him not getting a certain promotion he wanted and later on even fired.
This shows that Abe, who dresses typical American on the beginning of the play, integrated well into the American society as he respects American values but is still valuing his other identity.
Amir on the other hand, tries to hide away his other identity, suppressing his own emotions towards it and tries to be as American as possible.

Nevertheless it's clear that they're both afraid of being discriminated against because of their Muslim identity, this is also why they both changed their names to not be associated as Muslim right away.

Throughout the course of the play Amir admits at a dinner party with his work colleague, an African-American woman, and her husband Isaac, an art creator working with Emily, that he felt a blush when 9/11 happendhappened and ends up spitting Isaac in his face and beating his wife.
All of these situations are signs of Amir's second identity and his opperessedoppressed emotions coming up.
The last scene, which is also the one displayed have takes place around eight months after the dinner party.

Amir and Emily are separated and Amir had a lot of time to think about how he acted exactly the way he always hated about the Islamic culture and ended up portraying the stereotypes which are usually used to patronize muslims.
In this scene Abe asks his uncle Amir on how to act now that the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation interrogated him.

Right in the beginning it's noticable how Abe is clearly mad at the American authorities and its government as he accuses them of going into the Muslim community and looking for people who'swhose immigration status might be out for renewal so that they can deport them more easily.
Amir on the other hand tells Abe that they might feel like he was antagonizing towards them as he laughed in their faces when they asked about his immigration status (cf. l. 7).
He calls a lawyer for advice (cf. l. 19) and tries to explain, that Abe has to mindful and careful about what message he's sending the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation.

Amir shows a completely different attitude towards American authorities as Abe as he makes it clear that he understands that there's always a chance of getting deported and that the American authorities, in this case the FBIFederal Bureau of Investigation, make the rules, not him.
He states that he's on the side of the American government and asks Abe to rethink his decision of going against them.
Abe is clearly showing that he's more rebellious and even states that getting deported might not be so bad at all.
He almost shows no respect to the American authorities and it's noticable now he doesn't think much of them (cf. l. 58).

In the next paragraph Abe's and Amir's argument is getting more heated as Abe screams out that Amir's life isn't so good after all, that he lost his job because he was hiding his Muslim identity, making it seem like he was hiding something, lost his friends and his wife because he beat her face bloody and lost his American status.
Moreover he tells Amir that he wants something from these people (l. 44) he won't get.
Here he is referring to the fact that Muslim people and the Muslim community is getting more and more judged and face daily discrimination more often.

Amir tried to build himself a typical American life, even the marriage seems to be a symbol of marrying an American when your ethnicity is not accepted, and it all crumbling in the end because he never respected his background.
He wanted to be seen as an American, just an American without migration background.
Abe states here that that was never possible as the American society has totoo many prejudice against the Islamic culture.
Amir adds that Abe did the same when he changed his name to Jensen (cf. l. 58).
This shows how Abe was sick of the American authorities making him trying to avoid being associated as a muslim.
Amir sees this totally different (cf. ll. 60-62) but Abe cuts him off and tells him that his community thinks Amir hates himself (cf. l. 55) and Abe agrees with them.
Abe explains how one can't just copy the Americans but needs to see himself as an American with a Muslim immigration background (cf. ll. 69-72).
After saying that Abe leaves.
This whole conversation shows that Abe and Abe share totally different opinions on how to be and act in the American society and end developing hatred for each other.

To sum it up one can see that Abe used to look up to his uncle in the first scene but ends up being discusteddisgusted by him, as Amir, in Abe's, can't be honest with himself and just wants to please the American society, be seen as one of them, which is not possible.
Turns out Abe and Amir were both right to be afraid of systematic and (un-)intentional racism, and of people who are patronizing them.
The difference is that Abe speaks up about it and Amir hides his emotions away, trying to please the authorities.
